DataElement.preferredName: Central Nervous System Surgical Margin Surgical Margin Status CNSMarginStatus
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The part of the nervous system that consists of the brain, spinal cord, and meninges.:One of the criteria for assessment of the effectiveness of given surgical procedure in achieving the local control of a neoplasm and the adequacy of tumor removal. It is defined by the tissue plane through which the dissection has been done and the actual or potential neoplastic tissue which has been left outside the boundary of a resected specimen within the patient. There are four types of surgical margins: intracapsular or intralesional, marginal, wide, and radical._One of the criteria for assessment of the effectiveness of given surgical procedure in achieving the local control of a neoplasm and the adequacy of tumor removal. It is defined by the tissue plane through which the dissection has been done and the actual or potential neoplastic tissue which has been left outside the boundary of a resected specimen within the patient. There are four types of surgical margins: intracapsular or intralesional, marginal, wide, and radical.:A condition or state at a particular time._Status for absence or presence of margin

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: One of the criteria for assessment of the effectiveness of given surgical procedure in achieving the local control of a neoplasm and the adequacy of tumor removal. There are four types of surgical margins: intracapsular or intralesional, marginal, wide, and radical.:To have a connection by participation or association or use; sharing in an activity or process.:A carcinoma that is not confined to the epithelium, and has spread to the surrounding stroma.
